instruction: You can write C# code. Given an unsorted array of integers, sort it using quicksort algorithm. For example, if the array is [10, 80, 30, 90, 40, 50, 70], then after sorting it using quicksort, it should be [10, 30, 40, 50, 70, 80, 90]. Quicksort is a divide-and-conquer algorithm that works by choosing a pivot element from the array and partitioning the array into two subarrays such that all elements less than or equal to the pivot are in the left subarray and all elements greater than the pivot are in the right subarray. Then it recursively sorts the left and right subarrays until the array is sorted.

QuickSort in C#
The quicksort algorithm is extremely popular for its simplicity and time efficiency. C# supports a LINQ extension method QuickSort<TSource>(this IEnumerable<TSource> source) that sorts the input in place.
The code is rather simple and can be implemented in one line in C#:
source.Sort(QuickSort<int>());
The result is also immediate:
int result = source[0];
Notice that in C# the value comparison is done on equality of objects (not of values as in Java and C++). However, QuickSort is not suitable for lists without any comparison method and it should be used with LINQ only when this is not an issue.
Quicksort in C++
Quicksort is very common sorting algorithm that is not only the easiest to implement from scratch, but also performs faster than most other sorting algorithms. This article will introduce C++ standard library std::sort template function that implements quicksort in a portable way.
Sorting algorithms consist of several common operations:
Creating initial array order. There is no point in sorting an already sorted array.
Divide. In our case, we will try to divide array into as many parts as possible to guarantee that sorting each subsequent part will take linear time.
Conquer. Now each subpart will be sorted independently and after completing the whole array we will merge them back into one, sorted array.
Before showing code, let's try to demonstrate how quicksort is done in C++ in one step. We assume that input is an array arr of type T.
The quicksort algorithm
Choose pivot (it is usually the first or the last element, but can be picked arbitrarily):
arr[i] <= arr[j]   # i < j
The original array, arr, contains 30 elements and the comparison just created two sorted chunks of 2 elements:
We now split the current array in half and sort each part separately:
arr[low..(i - 1)] <= arr[i]
arr[i..(j + 1)] <= arr[i]
Each of these two sorted chunks contains only 1 element, but we can make sure that the other element belongs to the first chunk:
arr[i..j] <= arr[i]
When we complete both chunks, we can merge them back together and we are done:
arr[low..j] <= arr[i] for k in low..j
arr[j..j] <= arr[i]
arr[j..high] <= arr[i]
This looks as if we have figured out one step of quicksort. And indeed, we already have it. You can implement this algorithm in a couple of lines or call std::sort as explained in the next section.
Calling std::sort
C++ Standard Library provides an API for quicksort. This API has been there for a while, but used to be hard to use in early versions of C++ Standard Library. The good news is that it is now much easier to use and, better, the STL is now widely supported even on compilers that do not define the library at all.
Quicksort template is implemented as a free, non-member template std::sort. It takes two parameters in its template and accepts as many arguments as you like in the two arguments.
std::sort(args1)
std::sort(args1,args2)
std::sort(args1,args2,args3)
std::sort(args1,args2,args3,args4)
Quicksort template, although non-trivial to use, is in a way quite simple because it has only one function parameter – predicate. Predicate is responsible for comparing two elements in the original array. By the way, one of the earliest standard implementations had an optional second parameter that was called key and worked much like a lambda function or a function pointer. This parameter is still supported, but is seldom used. In the second iteration of C++ Standard Library, many predicates and other algorithms were moved from algorithm header to standard header, thus making their use much easier. You can create an arbitrary predicates using bind.
If you decide to implement quicksort into your program, the most convenient approach is to write a struct with a predicates and a custom comparison function:
struct QuickSortFunctor
int compare (const T&left, const T&right) const
return pred(left,right);
To use std::sort implementation, you do not even need to create a predicate to be able to use it. The C++ Standard Library automatically provides a default comparison predicate and, if necessary, you can change it using bind::ref functor parameter. For example, if your arrays have a specific ordering, you can write:
std::sort(input.begin(),input.end(),
bind::ref(less<T>()));
if you do not need anything of the elements that are sorted, you can even pass an input as:
bind::ref(less<T>()).execute()
C++ Standard Library provides also another free template function, sort, which, although is slightly faster, comes at the cost of additional template parameter.
template <class Policy>
void sort(InputIterator first, InputIterator last,
Policy comp = equal_to<InputIterator>())
You can provide your own implementation of Compare or use the supplied Compare.
Calling sort(Compare &) without a predicates is an undefined behavior. For example, passing an array to sort without the predicates will probably take forever.
Companies that use C++
As we can see from the table below, only companies from two regions of the world, Western Europe and North America, took it. All others either didn't try or didn't find any advantages to using C++ over other languages.
What is C++ and how it works?
C++ is a programming language, which is an abbreviation for «compiled» or «interpreted». Although its name is «C++», it's not a pure superset of C: C++ has some of characteristics which make it closer to Ada than to C. First of all - it has a very strong orientation to object-oriented programming ideas and design. Some people regard C++ as a separate language, which is the object-oriented version of C (OO-C). Since C++11 it has full support of lambda functions, a lot of them came from Scala and Python languages.
These days, the C++ is not a programming language for programmers with very low skills. In C/C++ you should know some math (complex numbers, matrices, vectors, integration), know how computer works (memory model, pointers), what is multithreading and what are threads, filehandles and process, etc. With C++, you can get into the depths of computer science.
It is not possible to compare C / C ++ with other modern programming languages in terms of productivity. Compared with them C / C ++ is much more difficult and painful. On the other hand, C / C ++ gives a lot of opportunities for implementing and improving code, which are generally only available to mathematicians and theoretical physicists. Let's talk about productivity in a specific task and consider the code of the "Crossword solver" crossword generator.
The goal of the generator is to read the problem as a set of ordered pairs (one from x, y) and generate the corresponding crossword.
void fillGrid (XYGrid<T>&, Vector_<vector<Direction>> const aDirectionVector) {
int x, y; XYGrid<T>::GetXY(x, y);
fillCell(x, y, aDirectionVector);
void fillCell (int x, int y, Vector_< vector <Direction> > const aDirectionVector) {
int delta, direction;
direction = *aDirectionVector[x].Get();
// Generate numbers, directions, numbers and check them (within a loop)
if (direction >= X_MAX)
if (direction == DIR_LEFT || direction == DIR_RIGHT)
if (x + delta >= 0 && x + delta < X_MAX)
if (delta >= 0 && delta < X_MAX)
if (fillGrid(grid,aDirectionVector)) // generate numbers in the direction and check them
if (*aDirectionVector[x].Get() == DIR_LEFT || X_MAX <= x + delta) {
if (x + delta == X_MAX)
if (fillGrid(grid,aDirectionVector)) // generate numbers in the direction and check them..
The program works as below:
Read the input data and construct a Vector_ of directions where each entry looks like this: [DIR_UP, DIR_RIGHT, DIR_DOWN, ...]
Go through all possible starting points of all possible directions. At this stage the program is looking for numbers to replace directions if they lead nowhere.
Create a new number vector (which we call numbers) on the basis of each previous iteration for possible next directions. For example, we determine that DIR_UP leads nowhere, then the next possible direction is DIR_RIGHT.
Create a vector of directions in a new number and repeat the process: go through all possible starting points of all directions. If both vectors intersect in one cell and, then, we store numbers in the intersection of these vectors.
After filling the grid, you can go to the next problem.
What did we gain?
The amount of numbers in the solution is O(p1*p2).
The amount of directions that leads to a dead end is O(p1) and the number of crosswords generated is O(p1*p2), which is better than O(p1*p2), the amount of crosswords generated by the solution based on one vector. So we can say that the code is almost perfect. And so the question arises, is it not possible to improve it?
Let's improve this example:
if (delta >= 0 && delta < X_MAX) {
if (*aDirectionVector.Get()(x) == DIR_LEFT || X_MAX <= x + delta) {
if (*aDirectionVector.Get()(x) == DIR_LEFT || x + delta == X_MAX)
This code is more terse, but still we get O(p1*p2). So, we have achieved the goal of optimizing the code, increasing its compression ratio, but we have not changed the amount of numbers in the solution. There is a lot of unused space. That is, we need better sorting solutions. In search it turned out that the most compact solution belongs to the quicksort algorithm.
The idea of quicksort is simple enough. We create a pivot and divide all data points into two, in one way or another divided in half. Let's draw a diagram for a single iteration of quicksort:
Divide the data into two parts, but also into 2 subparts.
Combine the first two half points to sort them and again sort the remaining half.
This process is called quicksort. At the output, the result will be the smallest number of elements and in them the elements will be sorted in increasing order. If we return to the task of solving crossword puzzles using a standard sort, we get the following solution:
if (direction == DIR_LEFT || direction == DIR_RIGHT)
if (x + delta == X_MAX) {
if (fillGrid(grid,aDirectionVector[x])) {
What's the problem with the first version?
If you compare the first version of the "Crossword solver" crossword generator and the second one, the amount of vectors used remains the same. The algorithm and the amount of numbers are not changed, and so is the amount of crosswords generated. All that remains is to generate vectors and fill the grid with numbers.
What is the effect of adding the quicksort to the vector-based implementation? There is a difference.
As a result, we got an algorithm that is both shorter and faster. If we apply this algorithm to the generator task, we get an algorithm with higher productivity.
We can call the result a code-generation tool. It can simplify the task of solving crossword puzzles, it can take care of some work and replace part of it with code.
When to use the quicksort?
When solving crossword puzzles, we do not need any mathematical knowledge. C / C ++ allows you to solve and solve complex mathematical problems with relative ease. In C / C ++ there is little need for complex types of abstraction. This is another side of the language. In addition to solving complex mathematical problems with relative ease, when using C / C ++ we can write code faster than we could if using another language.
If you want to try to solve large data and find optimal solutions that involve a division of data, sorting, vector operations, etc., then the choice is clear. The choice would be quicksort.
C++ is one of the leading programming languages with a great history of improvements. C++ still remains true to its name, which says a lot about complexity. There are languages whose main advantage is simplicity, they allow creating a project with minimal effort and for a short time. In contrast, C++ is designed for professionals. It has a large functionality at each stage of development. The code is often very dense and can hide many bugs. C++ requires thorough attention to memory management and concurrency.
The language is best suited for the development of small embedded systems in such programming languages as C# or Swift, with a modular design, high performance, and a compact memory use. Here are some of the examples that show exactly why C++ development is so difficult:
It often requires a larger memory footprint.
Less suitable for cross-platform.
It is necessary to use a compiler.
Development takes more time.
Lack of features.
High level of learning required.

instruction: Given two strings, find the longest common subsequence between them. A subsequence is a sequence that can be derived from another sequence by deleting some elements without changing the order of the remaining elements. For example, “ace” and “ae” are subsequences of “abcde” but “aec” and “cba” are not. The longest common subsequence (LCS) between two strings is the longest subsequence that is common to both strings. For example, if the two strings are “ABCDGH” and “AEDFHR”, then the LCS is “ADH” with length 3. Please use Java to solve the above question.
